ygData.subject: Search behaviour
ygData.msgSnippet: Well, I was on a roll there for a bit but now I m back to hitting my head on the brick wall (much like my cat). My initial goal was to evolve 5 behaviours: 1)

Well, I was on a roll there for a bit but now I'm back to hitting my
head on the brick wall (much like my cat).

My initial goal was to evolve 5 behaviours:

1) Go to static mouse when he sees him (starts in sight)
2) Go to moving away mouse that always stays in view
3) Go to mouse moving towards that always stays in view
4) Go to last mouse location known when mouse goes out of sight
5) Explore map in an attempt to find the mouse when no sighting has
occurred yet (mouse is static).

So using my fully connected recurrent NN, and evolving the weights
only, I managed to solve the first 4.  The fifth one, however, has not
been successful to this point.

I have not found any material that covers a problem like this, so I'm
taking a shot in the dark here with my approach, but it seems sound to
me.  As mentioned, I provide 4 inputs, one for each direction, that
tells the cat how 'desirable' it is to go in a particular direction -
based upon how long ago he was on the tiles in that direction.  -1.0
means there is only a wall in that direction, 0.0 means he was just
there (so it's not so desirable) and +1.0 means he has never been
there (so it's very desirable).

Originally I tried using my genomes evolved through the first 4
scenarios on scenario 5 with no luck.  So then I evolved some genomes
through scenario 1 and tried them on scenario 5.  No luck.  So at the
moment I am evolving newly created genomes on scenario 5 and it isn't
going so hot thus far.  The 'desirability' inputs don't seem to be
doing the trick.  Out of the 36 starting positions, the cat can solve
32 at best, but there is still a lot of pulsating back and forth for
several ticks here and there.  It seems plain to me that I am in need
of a better input system to have searching behaviour emerge.

Of course even if the cat does evolve to solve all 36 starting
positions, I am not optimistic about its chances with the other
scenarios on top of it.  With another input (4-7: U,R,D,L) for
proximity to mouse that needs to drive the cat's direction, it seems
that it is too difficult for the cat to have two separate sets of
inputs controlling its direction (when mouse not present, then use
'desirability').

Here's a screenshot illustrating 3 cat start positions and 3 mouse
starting positions.  The two that start in intersections go together
and then others go with the appropriate position that would require
the cat to change directions after initially choosing one.

http://www.redcrocodile.net/test/nolog/CatAndMouse_Search.jpg

I only have 4 more days for my experiments after this, so it's all
coming to a close shortly, but I figured that I'd put this out there
to see if anyone has any ideas.  I could mess around with the inputs
and perhaps change these 4 that I use for 'desirability', but there is
no time for major overhauls.

Again, the restrictions on the experiment are that he can only receive
inputs that would be available to a cat in a real scenario (no
cheating) and he must decide on a movement every game tick (no using
last direction and moving continually until told to stop).

Cheers,
Mike
